item.title: Pokemon TCG Pocket Secluded Springs Booster Pack Revealed for Next Week
item.content:encoded:
The Pokemon Company and DeNA have announced a brand new themed booster pack expansion for Pokemon TCG Pocket, and it's bringing a ton of new cards for you to collect next week.

Arriving on August 28th, Secluded Springs, like Eevee Grove and Shining Revelry before it, is a themed booster pack rather than a mainline expansion (like Wisdom of Sea and Sky), which effectively means that it's bringing fewer cards and no seismic gameplay changes to Pokemon TCG Pocket.

That doesn't mean you can't expect lots of new cards, though, and true to form, Secluded Springs will bring brand new digital goodies for you, including a gorgeous new Suicune ex card, a new full-art Milotic, and more.

You can also look forward to new cards depicting the likes of Entei and Raikou, as well as Mantyke, Slowking, and other 'mons you might find around a hot spring area. By the looks of the art that's been shown for the expansion so far, it's all lovely high-quality stuff, too.

Of course, there's no guarantee that the art for these cards won't turn out to have been inadvertently stolen from fanart pieces, but at least we can probably expect The Pokemon Company to act quickly if that does turn out to be the case.

Just in case you're not familiar with Pokemon TCG Pocket, it's a mobile version of the popular Pokemon TCG card game that simplifies combat rules and renders your collection digitally rather than physically.

It's got plenty of cards from the main game to collect, as well as a number of unique art pieces you can only find within Pokemon TCG Pocket itself, and hey, it's free to play, so you may as well check it out, right?

Pokemon TCG Pocket is available to play now on Android and iOS, and its Secluded Springs themed booster pack launches on August 28th.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Escape from Tarkov 1.0 Release Date Set for November
item.content:encoded:
Escape from Tarkov developer and publisher Battlestate Games has announced that the game's 1.0 release finally has a release date, and it's just around the corner.

In a new trailer titled "Prepare for Escape" (which is pretty brief and doesn't feature too much in the way of gameplay footage), a man can be seen typing code on a screen, interspersed with footage of soldiers in camo gear engaging in firefights.

Eventually, amidst blaring alarms, the man types a single date on the screen: November 15th. Technically speaking, the trailer doesn't specifically say that this is Escape from Tarkov's 1.0 release date, but it's hard to imagine what else could warrant this kind of fanfare.

Battlestate first teased a 1.0 release for Escape from Tarkov this year back in April, and the studio confirmed that the game will be coming to Steam then as well, although whether that'll happen alongside the 1.0 launch remains to be seen.

Escape from Tarkov was first released in closed beta back in 2017, and since then, it's undergone a number of changes thanks to consistent updates (and progress wipes to go along with them, of course).

The game has also spawned a spinoff in the form of Escape from Tarkov: Arena, a more traditional FPS that forgoes Tarkov's wide-open areas and PvPvE gameplay for more straightforward player-versus-player deathmatch engagements.

If you wish, you can check out the new Preapre for Escape trailer right here. It doesn't give too much away other than the date, but it's a fun little creation on Battlestate's part regardless.

Escape from Tarkov is, as far as we know, due to launch in full on November 15th this year. If you want to check it out ahead of that date, you can pick up its beta right now on PC. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Bungie CEO Pete Parsons Steps Down After Over 20 Years
item.content:encoded:
Bungie CEO Pete Parsons has announced he's stepping down after over 20 years with the company, and he'll be handing his responsibilities over to another long-time Bungie staffer.

In an announcement on the official Bungie website, Parsons says he's "decided to pass the torch" and that now is the "right time for a new beginning", but he doesn't elaborate on his reasons for leaving any further than that.

Parsons will be handing his CEO role over to Justin Truman, who previously served as Destiny 2's General Manager and the chief development officer of Bungie as a whole. It sounds as though the transition will be instantaneous, since no other date is given.

Truman begins his own message by reminding fans of his credentials; he worked as a coder for the original Destiny and served as a designer on Destiny 2, crafting many systems for the game (including the endgame mechanisms, which he says he got "terribly wrong" at launch).

He's also been helping Bungie to develop Marathon, so it's fair to say he's been across everything the studio has worked on for the last ten years or so. It's easy to see why Parsons picked Truman for a successor.

Truman inherits a Bungie that is, to put it charitably, struggling somewhat. Marathon's rollout isn't exactly going smoothly; the game was originally due to launch in September, but was delayed to an unspecified point in the future following lackluster feedback from the first closed alpha test.

The extraction shooter also found itself in hot water back in May, when it was revealed that artwork used in the game had been taken from an online artist without permission or compensation (which, incidentally, is not the first time Bungie has been caught doing something like this).

That's all in addition to the fact that the latest Destiny 2 expansion, The Edge of Fate, hasn't exactly been rapturously received, so it looks like Truman has his work cut out if he wants to turn Bungie's fortunes around. We'll have to wait and see whether he achieves that goal.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
